repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
# Introduction
This PR is PoC for approach for generating and using shared library of internal utiity code. Cython currently creates pretty big .so files which causes issues for the clients see #6042, #6045, https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/27767. Proposed approach generates shared library containing MemoryView utility code which is loaded via standard cimport mechanism.

# Example
Consider following .pyx file:

```cython
def add_one(int[:] buf):
    for x in range(buf.shape[0]):
        buf[x] += 1
```
When compiling using command `cythonize -3fib test.pyx`, cython will produce binary with size **`774K`**. With this PR, the resulting binary size is **`192K`**.

> [!NOTE]  
> The size of the shared library is 805K but this size is shared with multiple files instead to be included n-times.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Generate shared library - this step generates .C file containing Memoryview utility code (for now only from `Utility/MemoryView.pyx`). New utility `cython_shared_module` is used for the purpouse:
   ```
   cython_shared_module
   
   gcc -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O2 -Wall -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat - 
   Werror=format-security -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time - 
   D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fPIC -I/root/dev/cython311/include -I/usr/include/python3.11 -c MemoryView.o
   
   gcc -shared -Wl,-O1 -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fstack-protector- 
   strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 MemoryView.o -o MemoryView.cpython- 
   311-x86_64-linux-gnu.so
   ```
2. Compile your `.pyx` code:
   ```
   cython -3 --use-shared-utility=CYSHARED_PKG test.pyx
   
   x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc -Wsign-compare -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O2 -Wall -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat - 
   Werror=format-security -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fstack-protector-strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time - 
   D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 -fPIC -I/root/dev/cython311/include -I/usr/include/python3.11 -c test.c -o 
   test.o
   
   x86_64-linux-gnu-gcc -shared -Wl,-O1 -Wl,-Bsymbolic-functions -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fwrapv -O2 -g -fstack-protector- 
   strong -Wformat -Werror=format-security -Wdate-time -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2 test.o -o 
   test.cpython-311-x86_64-linux-gnu.so
   ```
3. Import and use the compiled example:
   > Note: `MemoryView` library must be located in the `CYSHARED_PKG` Python path:
   ```python
   >>> import test
   >>> from array import array
   >>> a = array('i', [1,2,3])
   >>> test.add_one(a)
   >>> a
   array('i', [2, 3, 4])

   ``` 

# Implementation
Implementation consist of following parts:
* `@cname` decorator was extended to support also function declarations
* .pxd pipeline was extended to support `@cname` decorators
* `.pxd` file was added to `Utility.MemoryView.pyx`, `shared` section was carved out which is not included anymore to the compiled files
* Build pipeline was extended to add shared library to cimported libraries
* New pipeline and CLI `cython_shared_library` was added to generate new shared library

# Open questions to be answered
- [x] How we will provide shared library to the users:
       - users can generate shared library or 
       - Cython can provide pip dependency package for that (here can be issue how we will manage versions)
- [ ] How will look CLI for generating shared library and to instruct compiler to use shared library instead of generating Utility Code
- [x] How we will control which functions are loaded - this will be problem in future when more and more utility code will be able to include in shared library


# Future improvements
- [ ] For now *only* part of MemoryView code is included but there is possibility to include other cython Utility code
- [ ] C Utility code is also possible to shared code which will save even more binary size. I have dirty PoC for that.
- [ ] shared library .pxd file can/should be templated
- [ ] shared library should be tested in CI/CD


Fixes #2356

comment_data.body: This is workaround to allow compiling source files not based on real files.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         file_desc = pos[0]

-            raise RuntimeError("Only file sources for code supported")
+        # if not isinstance(file_desc, FileSourceDescriptor):

comment_data.body: `__Pyx_memviewslice` is hardcoded instead of templated value similar to the .pyx file. I think this needs to be fixed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,190 @@
+# from cpython cimport ...
+from __future__ import absolute_import
+
+cimport cython
+cdef extern from "Python.h":
+    ctypedef struct PyObject
+
+cdef extern from "pythread.h":
+    ctypedef void *PyThread_type_lock
+
+cdef extern from *:
+    ctypedef struct __Pyx_memviewslice:
+        pass
+
+    ctypedef struct __pyx_buffer "Py_buffer":
+        PyObject *obj
+
+    ctypedef struct __Pyx_TypeInfo:
+        pass
+
+    cdef struct __pyx_memoryview "__pyx_memoryview_obj":
+        Py_buffer view
+        PyObject *obj
+        __Pyx_TypeInfo *typeinfo
+
+    ctypedef int __pyx_atomic_int_type
+
+    __Pyx_memviewslice slice_copy_contig "__pyx_memoryview_copy_new_contig"(
+                                 __Pyx_memviewslice *from_mvs,
+                                 char *mode, int ndim,
+                                 size_t sizeof_dtype, int contig_flag,
+                                 bint dtype_is_object) except * nogil
+    bint slice_is_contig "__pyx_memviewslice_is_contig" (
+                            __Pyx_memviewslice mvs, char order, int ndim) nogil
+    bint slices_overlap "__pyx_slices_overlap" (__Pyx_memviewslice *slice1,
+                                                __Pyx_memviewslice *slice2,

comment_data.body: Probably worth double-checking that these compiler directives are still applied. `binding` will generate a good deal of extra code

I haven't completely thought this through (so it may be nonsense) but:

some of the issues with `internal` come from loading this as utility code and doing `merge_in`.

I wonder if it'd be better to treat this code as the source of the module rather than as utility code?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,6 +21,52 @@ def abort_on_errors(node):
         raise AbortError("pipeline break")
     return node
 
+def create_shared_library_pipeline(context, scope, options, result):
+
+    def generate_tree_factory(context):
+        def generate_tree(compsrc):
+            from .Code import TempitaUtilityCode
+            from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+            from . import MemoryView
+            import os.path
+            import Cython
+
+            # Force to generate __Pyx_ExportFunction
+            Options.cimport_from_pyx = True
+
+            source_desc = compsrc.source_desc
+            full_module_name = compsrc.full_module_name
+
+
+            initial_pos = (source_desc, 1, 0)
+            scope = context.find_module(full_module_name, pos = initial_pos, need_pxd = 0)
+
+            tree = context.get_empty_tree(source_desc, scope, pxd=False, full_module_name=full_module_name)
+
+            tree.is_pxd = False
+            tree.compilation_source = compsrc
+            tree.scope = scope
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.shared_view_utility_code)

comment_data.body: Yeah my initial view is that it'd be better if it knew these came from the pxd file. But I don't think this workaround is too bad - shared memoryviews are clearly a special case.

comment_data.body: (directives are a few lines above, but this is where github let me put the comment)

It is possible but then we will generate multiple .so libraries that user needs to manage instead of one. Currently this PR generates one `MemoryView` .so library just for sake of simplicity. But in final solution we can generate one single `libcython` .so file. I think this should be also in the list of questions to be answered.

comment_data.body:
> I think this should be also in the list of questions to be answered.

Now I am thinking that Utility code contains dependencies and if we are targeting multiple .so files, we will need to manage all dependencies via cimports between the libraries which is not ideal I suppose.

comment_data.body: I wasn't really suggesting multiple .so files - I think we should target just one. I'm was just wondering if there's a way to compile the code without treating it as "utility code" and so making everything internal.

comment_data.body: You can probably just use star-unpacking into a list literal here instead of `list(chain())`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -21,6 +21,52 @@ def abort_on_errors(node):
         raise AbortError("pipeline break")
     return node
 
+def create_shared_library_pipeline(context, scope, options, result):
+
+    def generate_tree_factory(context):
+        def generate_tree(compsrc):
+            from .Code import TempitaUtilityCode
+            from .UtilityCode import CythonUtilityCode
+            from . import MemoryView
+            import os.path
+            import Cython
+
+            # Force to generate __Pyx_ExportFunction
+            Options.cimport_from_pyx = True
+
+            source_desc = compsrc.source_desc
+            full_module_name = compsrc.full_module_name
+
+
+            initial_pos = (source_desc, 1, 0)
+            scope = context.find_module(full_module_name, pos = initial_pos, need_pxd = 0)
+
+            tree = context.get_empty_tree(source_desc, scope, pxd=False, full_module_name=full_module_name)
+
+            tree.is_pxd = False
+            tree.compilation_source = compsrc
+            tree.scope = scope
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.shared_view_utility_code)
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.memviewslice_init_code)
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.typeinfo_to_format_code)
+            context.include_directories.append(os.path.join(os.path.split(Cython.__file__)[0], 'Utility'))
+            return tree
+
+        return generate_tree
+
+    return list(
+        itertools.chain(
+            [generate_tree_factory(context)],
+            create_pipeline(context, 'pyx', exclude_classes=()),
+            [inject_pxd_code_stage_factory(context),
+            inject_utility_code_stage_factory(context),
+            abort_on_errors],
+            [generate_pyx_code_stage_factory(options, result)],
+        )
+    )

comment_data.body: Haven't looked into the details either, but generally speaking, we should keep this as close to a regular extension module (and its build procedure) as possible.

             result_sink = create_default_resultobj(source, self.options)

comment_data.body: The fully qualified module name needs to be configurable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,52 @@
+import argparse
+import tempfile
+import sys
+import os
+import shutil
+
+from Cython.Compiler import Options
+from Cython.Compiler import Pipeline
+from Cython.Compiler import Errors
+from Cython.Compiler import Main
+from Cython.Compiler import Symtab
+from Cython.Compiler.StringEncoding import EncodedString
+from Cython.Compiler.Scanning import FileSourceDescriptor
+
+def generate_shared_module(dest_dir):
+    Errors.init_thread()
+    Errors.open_listing_file(None)
+    Options.use_shared_utility = True
+
+    options = Options.CompilationOptions(language_level = 3)
+    context = Main.Context.from_options(options)
+    scope = Symtab.ModuleScope('MemoryView', parent_module = None, context = context, is_package=False)
+
+
+    with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmpdirname:
+        pyx_file = os.path.join(tmpdirname, 'MemoryView.pyx')
+        c_file = os.path.join(tmpdirname, 'MemoryView.c')
+        with open(pyx_file, 'w'):
+            pass
+        source_desc = FileSourceDescriptor(pyx_file)
+        comp_src = Main.CompilationSource(source_desc, EncodedString('MemoryView'), os.getcwd())

comment_data.body: This hits more than just the memory view code: e.g. coroutines.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -177,7 +177,7 @@ def extend_if_not_in(L1, L2):
             # Ensure that we don't generate import code for these entries!
             for entry in scope.c_class_entries:
                 entry.type.module_name = self.full_module_name
-                entry.type.scope.directives["internal"] = True
+                entry.type.scope.directives["internal"] = False if Options.use_shared_utility else True

+
+            # Force to generate __Pyx_ExportFunction
+            Options.cimport_from_pyx = True
+
+            source_desc = compsrc.source_desc
+            full_module_name = compsrc.full_module_name
+
+            initial_pos = (source_desc, 1, 0)
+            scope = context.find_module(full_module_name, pos = initial_pos, need_pxd = 0)
+
+            tree = context.parse(source_desc, scope, pxd = 0, full_module_name = full_module_name)
+
+            tree.is_pxd = False
+            tree.compilation_source = compsrc
+            tree.scope = scope
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.memoryview_utility_code)
+
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.memviewslice_init_code)
+            scope.use_utility_code(MemoryView.typeinfo_to_format_code)

comment_data.body: This shouldn't be necessary in `language_level=3`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,190 @@
+# from cpython cimport ...
+from __future__ import absolute_import

comment_data.body:
Yesterday I did investigation. It seems that implementing it as module directive can be tricky. Cython is using utility code in places not related to the module and hence information about module directives is missing -e.g.:

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/7aae6dba0248e929cb29ac0c03068de7b43b2735/Cython/Compiler/CythonScope.py#L125

Therefore, I will keep this for later.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,6 +147,7 @@ def __repr__(self):
 #: Number of function closure instances to keep in a freelist (0: no freelists)
 closure_freelist_size = 8
 
+use_shared_utility = None

commit.message: Move common functinality to external library
Implement cimporting shared library to compiled file
Generate shared module from real file instad of creating workaround
Remove manual creation of empty tree

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Generate and use shared library for MemoryView Utility code
